title: Chris Paul jokingly asks new Rockets star Russell Westbrook to leave Thunder locker room
text:
CLOSE Are Westbrook and Harden going to be able to collaborate well enough to get the Rockets to the championship? USA TODAY

HOUSTON — The fiery point guard entered the Thunder’s locker room. Within seconds, Russell Westbrook heard a stern and playful message.

“You’re in the wrong locker room,” a few Thunder players joked.

Westbrook refused to listen. The Houston Rockets had just finished with a 116-112 win over the Oklahoma City Thunder on Monday, marking Westbrook’s first start against his former team since the Thunder dealt him in an offseason trade for Chris Paul and a handful of future draft picks. So after bulldozing his way toward a near triple-double in points (21), rebounds (12) and assists (nine), Westbrook wanted to show the nicer side to his personality and catch up with old friends.

Too bad the Thunder’s current point guard jokingly became unpleasant.

“The Clippers tried to suspend me for this,” Paul joked, referring to when the Rockets attempted to barge into the Clippers’ locker room following contentious on-court exchanges during a 2018 game. “Come on man. You got to get out of here.”

Should any of this have been surprising? Both Westbrook and Paul faced their former team with the determination to exert their influence at nearly every moment.

Though James Harden led the Rockets with 40 points on plenty of shooting from the field (9-of-21), from 3-point range (3-of-14) and the free-throw line (21-of-22), Westbrook arguably had a bigger influence on shaping the Rockets' identity. He fueled a 10-0 run to open the third quarter that included a rebound, layup and assist. He pushed the pace any chance he could. And he did so without allowing any warm feelings about the Thunder to compromise his on-court intensity.

“When I hoop, I have no friends. On the court, they know not to talk to me," Westbrook said. “When I’m inside those lines, there are no friends. Spalding – that’s my friend, and my teammates.”

Russell Westbrook on facing OKC: “When I’m hooping, I have no friends.” pic.twitter.com/DFbn5jN8cC — Mark Medina (@MarkG_Medina) October 29, 2019

Paul shared a similar mentality, but he finished with different results. Paul had 15 points on only 6-of-14 shooting, five rebounds and four assists, a performance as low-key as the respectful reception he received during lineup introductions before a half-empty arena. He missed his first four shots and did not score until 54.9 seconds were left in the first half. He missed a potential game-tying 3 with about 1:47 remaining. Paul only seemed nostalgic when he watched the Rockets’ tribute video of him following the first timeout with 5:57 left in the first quarter.

“Extremely grateful. The fans were always great to me and my family,” said Paul, who then named some of the Rockets’ staff members. “Some of the people here became like family to me. I tried to stay in touch with those who were as genuine as could be.”

Interesting that Paul made those comments without mentioning Rockets owner Tillman Fertitta, general manager Daryl Morey or Harden. He even joked that he might get in trouble for talking every day to Rockets forward P.J. Tucker and reserve Gary Clark. Still, Paul and others on the Rockets have downplayed reports that tension with Harden contributed to his departure. Harden also stressed he did not see Paul when the two got tangled up after he threw a lob to Westbrook in the third quarter.

Either way, the Rockets traded Paul to Oklahoma City for practical reasons.

Houston had acquired Paul in a sign-and-trade from the Los Angeles Clippers only two years ago, leaving the Rockets believing they finally had enough to unseat the Golden State Warriors. It became enough for the Rockets to land the No. 1 seed with 65 regular-season wins. It was not enough to win an NBA championship, though. Paul strained his right hamstring toward the end of a Game 5 win in the 2018 Western Conference finals. The Warriors then won the next two games, including a decisive Game 7 as the Rockets missed 27 consecutive 3-pointers.

Paul struggled to stay durable the following season. He missed a combined 17 games with a strained left hamstring, and looked limited in the NBA playoffs. Paul also had various injuries with the Los Angeles Clippers in the NBA playoffs in 2015 (left hamstring) and 2016 (right hand).

More: Rockets' D'Antoni exudes calm despite lame-duck status: 'It's not going to change the way I coach'

More: Brandon Ingram putting burden on himself to carry Pelicans without Zion Williamson

Still, Rockets coach Mike D’Antoni argued that the 34-year-old Paul is “going to be good for another four years if he wants.” Thunder coach Billy Donovan expressed similar optimism because of Paul’s meticulous training, dietary and sleeping habits.

“I’m going to continue to work,” Paul said. “There’s only 420 of these jobs. You’re not going to take my job because you outwork me.”

Russell took Paul’s job, though. The Rockets willingly mortgaged their future so that Harden and Westbrook could reunite for the first time in seven years since playing together with the Thunder (2009-2012). They showed plenty of chemistry in only their third game together in a Rockets uniform.

Houston Rockets guard Russell Westbrook dribbles the ball as Oklahoma City Thunder guard Chris Paul defends during the first quarter at Toyota Center. (Photo: Troy Taormina, USA TODAY Sports)

On one play, Harden threw a lob to Westbrook. On other plays, Westbrook routinely set up Tucker so many times for open 3’s that D’Antoni joked that Tucker “should take him out to dinner.” Shortly after forcing a turnover, Westbrook finished with a late third-quarter dunk that prompted him to yell.

“It’s up to me to be able to make sure my guys are ready to go,” Westbrook said. “And not just ready, but competing and playing hard because playing hard is something that is not an option for me. It’s something you have to take pride in. To get to that elite level, you have to do that every night.”

Beard to Brodie 🔥🔥🔥🔥🔥🔥🔥🔥🔥🔥🔥🔥🔥🔥🔥🔥🔥🔥🔥🔥🔥🔥🔥🔥🔥🔥🔥🔥🔥🔥🔥🔥 pic.twitter.com/PyulWYZWjC — Houston Rockets (@HoustonRockets) October 29, 2019

The Thunder will miss that about Westbrook. No matter. OKC still dealt Westbrook last summer to Houston for Paul, a pair of first-round selections (2024, 2026) and pick swaps (2021, 2025), a move that became necessary to retool following Paul George’s trade request to the Los Angeles Clippers. After spending 11 seasons in Oklahoma City, collecting a regular-season MVP award, two scoring titles and the majority of his triple-doubles, Westbrook no longer guides the Thunder with his unmatched speed, his scoring bursts, his playmaking and his rebounding.

Perhaps Westbrook’s presence would have made little difference, anyway. Following Kevin Durant’s departure three years ago, the Thunder have not advanced past the first round of the NBA playoffs. Without Paul, perhaps Russell’s efforts would have produced just empty calories. So, the Thunder dealt their last future Hall-of-Famer in hopes that they can select future ones in upcoming drafts. Meanwhile, the Thunder dealt Paul for second-year guard Shai Gilgeous-Alexander, veteran wing Danilo Gallinari and five first-round picks (2021, 2022, 2023 2024, 2026).

“Sometimes I have to tell myself to shut up,” Paul said about playing with a young roster. “There’s so much I want them to learn so fast and I try to show them as much as possible and tell them playing is one thing, but watching and studying the game is a whole other game.”

Those players might want to study Westbrook and Paul. They both barked at officials and picked up technical fouls for it. They directed their teammates. They spoke before and after the game with former coaches and teammates they held in high regard. Once the game started, though? Then they turned serious.

“You try to be my friend,” Westbrook said, “I ain’t going to say (expletive) to you.”

He said plenty in the Thunder locker room afterwards, though. So did Paul, who revealed his competitive side even during playful locker room banter.

Follow USA TODAY NBA writer Mark Medina on Twitter, Facebook and Instagram.
description: The Rockets' Russell Westbrook and the Thunder's Chris Paul faced each other for the first time since their offseason trade. CP3 even brought jokes!
